text: SIG's main sport's business is underwriting on US sportsbooks. There are rules that say that  sports  books need to be able to pay-out on every bet should players hit everything. Obviously, there's some impossibly complex parlays  in that book that will screw them, so they pay SIG for tail protection on this. It's an absolute cash-cow for SIG

text: It's rumours from HFT world (my industry), but the rumour is on the order of ~100m a year (ok a bit less than I claimed originally). The main thing is that they're exploiting a regulatory environment that requires casinos and sports books to pay for this protection, and they're one of the only players in the game.

text: If you’re an underwriter you are perfectly happy to pay out $10m to $1 bets on 100m-to-1 shots as there is a queue of people who will take a share of that action all day long. It’s so safe you can likely get a bank to cover you while you go to the bond markets if you need to… in fact your bank will be first in the queue on those bonds.

text: There are not many firms with 1. the balance sheet to insure a sports-book as large as someone like fan-duel, and 2. The ability to value the entire portfolio of parlays across multiple sports into a single number.

elements.text: There are not many firms with 1. the balance sheet to insure a sports-book as large as someone like fan-duel, and 2. The ability to value the entire portfolio of parlays across multiple sports into a single number.

text: That is a very interesting quant problem

elements.text: That is a very interesting quant problem

text: Most insurance under-writers can’t pay out everything hitting. It sometimes takes a bad beating as an industry (for example, Lloyd’s in the 1980s), but the model is mature enough nobody is going bust if everyone involved has done their maths and got the right excel spreadsheets. If that’s how they have positioned themselves in the sports betting market, good luck to them!

text: Indeed. Any single parlay probably has a max-loss, but when combined with the entire portfolio, you have some bizarre outcomes that if the stars align and tickets 1-100 all hit at the same time you could have a ~100m hole in your book

text: I assume the margins are large enough that they can get away with models that are 70% of the way there and focus on having traders ticking up/down parameters like in OMM, I know SIG likes more manual/intuitive trading vs full systematic, though they couldn’t look at flow on millions of different combinations of multiples. They could model correlation between bet types in generic cases and have the traders tweak them for specific matches, then price based on those discounts
